tit.e: "Henohenomoheji" (へのへのもへじ) face-like pictograph made up of letters from the Japanese language hiragana phonetic writing system.
"Henohenomoheji" (へのへのもへじ) face-like pictograph made up of letters from the Japanese language hiragana phonetic writing system.
tit.cmt: face-like pictograph made up of letters from the Japanese language hiragana phonetic writing system→次文で説明があるため削除

sen.j: へのへのもへじ は、これら7つの平仮名のみを使い人の顔を模した図柄を描く文字遊び（文字絵）である。
sen.e: "Henohenomoheji" face-like pictographs are created by playing around with and arranging 7 hiragana phonetic syllables to form the caricature of a human face as a picture (letter picture).
"Henohenomoheji" face-like pictographs are created by playing around with and arranging 7 hiragana phonetic syllables to form the caricature of a human face as a picture (letter picture).
"Henohenomoheji" face-like pictographs are created by playing around with and arranging seven hiragana phonetic syllables to form the caricature of a human face as a picture (letter picture).
sen.cmt: “Henohenomoheji”のクォーテーションを半角に修正、"7"をスペルアウト、余分なスペース消去

sen.e: he pictures are called "Henohenomoheji" caricatures.
he pictures are called "Henohenomoheji" caricatures.
Also called "Hehenonomoheji."
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に沿わないため訳し直しました。

sen.j: いつごろ考えられたのかは定かではないが、現在の顔文字の始祖的なものである。
sen.e: It is not clear when the "Henohenomoheji" caricatures were invented however, is thought to be a forerunner of present day emoticons.
It is not clear when the "Henohenomoheji" caricatures were invented however, is thought to be a forerunner of present day emoticons.
It is not clear when the "Henohenomoheji" caricatures were invented however, is thought to be a forerunner of present day emoticons.
sen.cmt: “Henohenomoheji”のクォーテーションを半角に修正

sen.j: 最初と2番目の「へ」が両の眉を、2つの「の」が両目を、「も」が鼻を、3番目の「へ」が口を、「じ」が顔の輪郭をそれぞれ表している。
sen.e: Each hiragana phonetic syllable has a function. The first and second "he" (へ) hiragana phonetic syllables form both eyebrows, the 2 "no" (の) hiragana phonetic syllables are used for the eyes, the "mo" (も) syllable forms the nose and the 3rd "he" (へ) syllable is used for the mouth, while the "ji" (じ) syllable forms the outline of the face.

Each hiragana phonetic syllable has a function. The first and second "he" (へ) hiragana phonetic syllables form both eyebrows, the 2 "no" (の) hiragana phonetic syllables are used for the eyes, the "mo" (も) syllable forms the nose and the 3rd "he" (へ) syllable is used for the mouth, while the "ji" (じ) syllable forms the outline of the face.

Each hiragana phonetic syllable has a function: the first and second 'he' (へ) hiragana phonetic syllables form both eyebrows, the two 'no' (の) hiragana phonetic syllables are used for the eyes, the 'mo' (も) syllable forms the nose and the third 'he' (へ) syllable is used for the mouth, while the 'ji' (じ) syllable forms the outline of the face.
sen.cmt: 二文に分かれているため一文になるよう修正、クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正、余分なスペース消去、"2""3rd"をスペルアウト

sen.j: 漫画、とくにギャグ漫画においては、ステレオタイプで典型的なかかしの顔としてしばしば用いられる。
sen.e: This face caricature is often used in manga, especially humorous manga, as a stereotyped scarecrow figure.
This face caricature is often used in manga, especially humorous manga, as a stereotyped scarecrow figure.
This face caricature is often used in manga, especially humorous manga, as a stereotyped scarecrow figure.

sen.j: 同様の文字の組み合わせとして「へのへのもへの」、「へめへめくつじ」、「へめへめしこじ」、「へねへねしこし」「しにしにしにん」(1, 2のしは横に、んはケツあご風に)になどがある。
sen.e: Similarly there are other versions that use different combinations of letters to represent other body parts.
Similarly there are other versions that use different combinations of letters to represent other body parts.

Similarly there are other versions that use different combinations of letters: 'Henohenomoheno' (へのへのもへの), 'Hemehemekutsuji' (へめへめくつじ), 'Hemehemeshikoji' (へめへめしこじ), 'Heneheneshikoshi' (へねへねしこし), and 'Shinishinishinin' (しにしにしにん; the first and second 'shi' (し) are drawn sideways and the 'n' (ん) is drawn like a cleft chin).
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に沿わないため訳し直しました。

sen.j: また、「つるニハ○○ムし」（つるにはまるまるむし）というものもあり、「つ」が禿頭、「る」が耳、「ニ」が額のしわ、「ハ」が両眉毛、「○○」が両目、「ム」が鼻、「し」が顔の輪郭をそれぞれ表し（口はない）、全体で老人の顔になる。
sen.e: represents a bald head, "ru" (る) the ears, "ni" (ニ) wrinkles on the brow, "ha" (ハ) the eyebrows, "OO" the eyes, "mu" (ム) the nose and the "shi" (し) syllable forms the outline of the face (there is no mouth) with each of the letters representing a part of an overall caricature of an elderly person's face.

represents a bald head, "ru" (る) the ears, "ni" (ニ) wrinkles on the brow, "ha" (ハ) the eyebrows, "OO" the eyes, "mu" (ム) the nose and the "shi" (し) syllable forms the outline of the face (there is no mouth) with each of the letters representing a part of an overall caricature of an elderly person's face.

Also, there is another version called 'Tsuruniha OO mushi' (つるニハOOムし): 'tsu' (つ) represents a bald head, 'ru' (る) the ears, 'ni' (ニ) wrinkles on the brow, 'ha' (ハ) the eyebrows, 'OO' the eyes, 'mu' (ム) the nose and the 'shi' (し) syllable forms the outline of the face (there is no mouth) with each of the letters representing a part of an overall caricature of an elderly person's face.
sen.cmt: 『また、「つるニハ○○ムし」（つるにはまるまるむし）というものもあり、「つ」が禿頭』の部分が抜けているため訳出、person’sのアポストロフィーを半角に修正、クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正、余分なスペース消去'tsu'→'tsu' (つ)に変更しました。

sen.j: また「二」を「三」に変えて「つる三は○○むし」とも。
sen.e: By changing "ni" two (二) to "san" three (三), the caricature is called a "Tsurusanha OO Insect" (つるニハOO in Japanese).
By changing "ni" two (二) to "san" three (三), the caricature is called a "Tsurusanha OO Insect" (つるニハOO in Japanese).
By changing 'ni' two (二) to 'san' three (三), the caricature is called a 'Tsurusanha OO mushi' ('つる三はOOむし' in Japanese).
sen.cmt: Tsurusanha OO Insect→Tsurusanha OO mushi とし、クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正、「つるニハ○○」→「つる三は○○むし」に修正、クォーテーション追加
